title: 112_hr2636
content: The "Neighborhood Preservation Act of 2011" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The findings section follows the short title. The Congress finds that allowing depository institutions, the GSEs, and affiliates to enter into long-term leases for foreclosed properties would help stabilize home values and restore confidence in the housing market. Allowing institutions or affiliates to lease foreclosed properties long-term can help stabilize the housing market by preserving property value and preventing losses upon property disposition. It also maintains the aesthetic and economic values of surrounding homes and neighborhoods. SEC. 3. BANK LEASING OF FORECLOSED PROPERTIES. Bank leasing of foreclosed properties is authorized under Section 18 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. Depository institutions and their affiliates can lease residential properties to individuals for up to 5 years, including lease with an option to purchase. Under Section 18 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act, depository institutions and their affiliates can lease residential properties for up to 5 years if the property was used as security for a loan and acquired through foreclosure or deed in lieu of foreclosure. Federal banking agencies will establish regulations for leasing activities, including minimum capital requirements, to ensure safety and soundness. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act allows depository institutions and affiliates to lease residential properties for up to 5 years under certain conditions. Federal banking agencies will establish regulations, including capital requirements, to ensure safety and soundness of the institution or affiliate. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act allows depository institutions and affiliates to lease residential properties for up to 5 years. Leases can be extended beyond 5 years if permitted by law. The section applies to leases entered into within a 3-year period from the enactment of the Neighborhood Preservation Act. Congress intends no permanent policy change regarding leasing foreclosed property by depository institutions. Subsection (y) of section 18 of the Act should not apply to leases entered into after the specified period. The Insurance Act does not apply to leases entered into after the specified sunset date. Government sponsored enterprises like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac can lease foreclosed properties to mitigate taxpayer losses and stabilize home prices for up to 5 years, as determined by the Federal Housing Finance Agency. This authority expires 3 years after the enactment of the Act.
